document_type: ISO 27001 Security Requirements - Annex A Control
applies_to_note: All gambling operators subject to RTS Chapter 4 - Security Requirements

control.control_purpose: To ensure proper and effective use of cryptography to protect confidentiality, authenticity and integrity of information according to business requirements and legal, regulatory and contractual obligations
control.control_objective: Define and implement rules for effective use of cryptography including key management procedures to protect information and ensure compliance with applicable laws

iso_27001_definition.official_text: Rules for the effective use of cryptography, including cryptographic key management, should be defined and implemented.
key_requirements: Rules for effective use of cryptography defined
Cryptography requirements based on information classification
Encryption of sensitive data at rest and in transit
Cryptographic key generation and distribution controlled
Key storage and protection procedures documented
Key compromise and recovery procedures in place

control_purpose_detail.purpose: Preventive control ensuring cryptography is used effectively to protect information and manage associated risks
control_purpose_detail.key_outcome: Confidentiality, authenticity and integrity of information protected through proper cryptography implementation and key management

prerequisites.description: Before implementing cryptography controls, foundational requirements must be met

required_prerequisites.rationale: Cryptography requirements determined by information classification level

required_prerequisites.description: Legal review of cryptography requirements and restrictions
required_prerequisites.rationale: Cryptography laws vary by jurisdiction and must be understood

required_prerequisites.description: Policy documenting encryption requirements by data type
required_prerequisites.rationale: Cryptography requirements defined in information handling policy

implementation_requirements.description: Review and document applicable cryptography laws and regulations

Regulations related to data protection and encryption
Export controls on cryptography where applicable
legal_review_process: Obtain legal professional advice on cryptography requirements
Document legal advice received and comply with recommendations
Review cryptography laws in all jurisdictions where data processed
Identify any restrictions on cryptography use
Update review when laws or regulations change
regulatory_compliance: GDPR requirements for data protection encryption
Payment Card Industry (PCI) DSS encryption requirements
UKGC requirements for customer data protection

implementation_requirements.description: Develop topic-specific cryptography and key management policy

cryptography_policy_content: Purpose and objectives of cryptography use
Encryption requirements by data classification level
Encryption key strength and cipher requirements
Confidential data encrypted at rest and in transit
key_management_policy: Logging and monitoring of key activities
policy_documentation: Policy communicated to all relevant personnel

implementation_requirements.description: Choose appropriate cryptographic standards and algorithms

standard_selection: Algorithm strength appropriate for data sensitivity
Key length meeting current security standards
Avoidance of weak or deprecated algorithms
approved_encryption: RSA for asymmetric encryption (2048-bit or stronger)
SHA-256 or stronger for cryptographic hashing
TLS 1.2 or 1.3 for data in transit encryption
algorithm_documentation: Review and update of algorithms annually

implementation_requirements.description: Deploy encryption for data stored on systems and devices

data_at_rest_encryption: File system encryption for storage devices
Endpoint encryption for desktop and laptop computers
Mobile device encryption for smartphones and tablets
implementation_approach: Use operating system built-in encryption where available
Deploy full disk encryption on endpoints
Implement application-level encryption for sensitive data
Encrypt temporary files and working data
sensitive_data_protection: Customer personal data encrypted at rest
Payment card data encrypted at rest
Financial transaction data encrypted at rest

implementation_requirements.description: Deploy encryption for data transmitted across networks

key_generation: Keys generated using cryptographically secure random sources
key_distribution: Key escrow procedures where legally required
Public key infrastructure (PKI) for key distribution
key_storage: Hardware security modules (HSM) for critical keys
Segregation of keys and encrypted data

implementation_requirements.description: Establish procedures for handling key compromise and recovery

key_loss_recovery: Key recovery from key escrow (if applicable)
key_backup: Backup keys stored separately from primary keys
Backup keys protected with same security as primary

implementation_requirements.requirement: Implement Key Management Logging and Monitoring
implementation_requirements.description: Establish logging and monitoring of cryptographic key activities

logging_requirements: Key generation logged with date, time and person
Key storage location and protection verified
Key usage logged for audit purposes
monitoring_activities: Monitoring of key management system operation
Alerts for suspicious key usage patterns
Regular review of key management logs
log_retention: Key management logs retained for investigation
Logs retained for period required by regulations
Audit trail of all key activities maintained

implementation_requirements.description: Ensure cryptography implementation achieves security objectives

confidentiality_objective: Strong encryption prevents data decryption attempts
integrity_objective: Message authentication codes verify data integrity
Tampered data detected through integrity checks
non_repudiation_objective: Digital signatures provide evidence of actions
authentication_objective: Cryptographic authentication of users and systems
Prevention of unauthorized access through authentication

implementation_requirements.description: Conduct testing to verify cryptography controls are functioning

testing_activities: Verify encryption is enabled and functioning
Test encryption at rest and in transit
Verify certificate validity and proper configuration
Test backup and recovery of keys
testing_frequency: Testing as part of internal audits

common_mistakes.description: Top 3 mistakes organizations make with cryptography

mistakes.description: Cryptographic keys not properly managed, stored or protected allowing key compromise or loss
root_cause: Lack of formal key management procedures
Keys stored insecurely or with insufficient access controls
No key backup or recovery procedures
Lack of awareness of key management importance
mistakes.impact: Key compromise exposes encrypted data, key loss prevents data access, audit failures, regulatory violations
prevention: Establish formal key management policy and procedures
Store keys in secure locations with access controls
Implement key backup and recovery procedures
Use hardware security modules for critical keys
Regular testing of key backup and recovery

mistakes.mistake: Use of weak encryption algorithms or key lengths
mistakes.description: Encryption using weak or deprecated algorithms or insufficiently long key lengths that can be broken
root_cause: Use of legacy or default encryption
Lack of understanding of encryption strength
Lack of security review during implementation
mistakes.impact: Encryption can be broken, data exposed, compliance violations, regulatory penalties
prevention: Use only industry-standard strong encryption algorithms
Implement minimum key lengths (AES-128 or stronger)
Use NIST and other standards as guidance

mistakes.description: Some data encrypted while other sensitive data is not encrypted creating inconsistent protection
root_cause: Lack of data classification to identify what needs encryption
mistakes.impact: Unencrypted sensitive data exposed, audit findings of non-compliance, data breaches
prevention: Classify all data by sensitivity level
Identify all data types requiring encryption
Implement encryption consistently across all systems

Key generation, storage and rotation procedures implemented
ukgc_application.compliance_requirement: Gambling operators must implement encryption for sensitive data with documented key management procedures to protect customer information and ensure compliance with UKGC and data protection requirements

gambling_operator_specific_guidance.customer_data_encryption: All customer personal data including names, addresses, identification information and contact details must be encrypted at rest and in transit. Customer account information and balances should be encrypted. Encryption protects customer privacy and supports GDPR compliance.
gambling_operator_specific_guidance.payment_card_protection: Payment card data must be encrypted per PCI DSS requirements. Card data should never be stored unencrypted. Communication with payment processors must use encryption. Encryption protects payment card information from interception or theft.
gambling_operator_specific_guidance.transaction_security: Wager transactions and game outcome information should be encrypted to protect transaction integrity and confidentiality. Transaction logging relies on encryption for integrity assurance. Encryption helps prevent dispute resolution issues from transaction tampering.
gambling_operator_specific_guidance.key_management_practicalities: For most gambling operators, key management is built into systems being used (HTTPS certificates managed by web servers, database encryption keys managed by databases, cloud key management by cloud providers). Understanding how keys are managed in these systems is sufficient. Document where keys are stored, who can access them and procedures if keys are lost or compromised.
gambling_operator_specific_guidance.audit_readiness: To be audit-ready: provide cryptography policy; provide list of encrypted data types; provide evidence of encryption implementation; provide key management documentation; show testing evidence; demonstrate certificate validity; provide incident response records for any encryption issues.
